job_title: Community Research Associate in Norman, OK
pros: We are, as a workforce, very mission-minded and research-driven. Seeing the patients and their families gives me hope and even when I have stressful days at work, I know that I'm here working for them. We have great access to scientific resources, awesome food, and fantastic benefits. (I had my car detailed on campus the other day instead of having to take it somewhere on my weekend. Nice!) I love that we have an on-site gym. I am so impressed with our new strategic plan, where we'll be increasing our workforce by over 2,000 people, including a ton of new faculty, which means a ton of new labs doing amazing science. And finally, we have facility dogs. My day is always better when I get to pet a dog at work.
cons: We're building a few new buildings which means some of our employees are temporarily moving off-campus until construction is complete. I dislike that I won't get to see some of my friends in other departments regularly, but I'm excited for our new clinical buildings!

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: They are very clear in giving expectations for their TAs during orientation.
cons: As an international student without any other options in the United States, I felt tricked when I discovered that I had been lied to regarding costs of living and our yearly stipend. Even before costs went up considerably, our stipend is clearly not enough to survive here and be able to afford basic services like healthcare and transportation, and the school offers little support or further options for international students. I would probably have rejected the offer if they had been honest with me. Feels like they are looking for cheap labor and not giving us an honest overview when we ask about life in the US. Either that, or the people in charge don't really know about life as a Graduate Student at their University.

review_title: OU Tulsa Information Technology Management Team = Dictatorship
job_title: Information Technology Analyst in Tulsa, OK
pros: Good benefits, nice people (outside of IT management), decent pay .
cons:
There is verbal/sexual harassment within the IT Department, even after being reported.
After a formal complaint was filed, I was met with retaliation that continued until the day that I left. 
HR protects upper management, but not others.
High turnover rate due to the culture within the IT Department. 
A transgender individual, who came out to the management team about transitioning, was met with harassment almost daily about their clothes,  the way they wore their hair, expressed concern about them using the gender assigned restroom, they even updated the Dress Code policy after they came out. This made it more difficult for that individual to continue working there. We followed the procedures HR has you take in-order to resolve these types of issues, but it only made it worse. WOULD NOT RECOMMEND !

review_title: getting worse despite more money in
pros: sunny weather; cheap cost of living; great dance & music programs; great museums; friendly students & faculty. Huge #s of brilliant students recruited w/full 5-year scholarships to anyone who wins National Merit Scholarship, also great Honors College + superb programs in Petroleum Engineering, Dance, Geology, Music (esp. vocal & organ), Classics (no grad program, but has brightest undergrads), German, Archeology, History, History of Science.
cons: little funding for humanities & social sciences; faculty retention is notoriously bad; legislature attacks faculty, administration publicly scapegoats faculty. Admin promises travel funding & other support, then fights tooth & nail to reject every penny in extremely time-consuming bait & switch operation employing the Orwellian "Concur" system. pros: The students and are far-and-away the main positive of the university. Another major pro is the opportunity to research and publish within areas of professional interest with a potential to make a meaningful contribution to the greater good.
cons: There is a major negative that surpassing all positives to working at OU as a faculty member: an unhealthy environment with insidiously deleterious effects on the well-being of many, including (very unfortunately) students. Workplace aggression, in both covert and overt forms, is common and bullies operate within the established university rules and policies. The dynamic began (to my knowledge) when administrators (even mid-level administrators rising from ranks of the faculty) began being paid over three times that of faculty. Even 15 years ago, this was unheard of, but it is now commonplace at OU. As a result, administrators, including mid-level administrators (e.g., department chairs, assistant deans) are loyal to upper administration, no longer loyal to "their" faculty, and even further out-of-touch with student needs. Mid level administrators are frequently expected (by upper administration) to somehow enforce practices that are not aligned with the faculty and not in the best interest of our students and/or to student education or training. Ultimately, this pressure on mid-level admin results in their support of the staff members under their employ, over their support of faculty. Staff members don't work for the university, faculty, or students; they work for the administration. This dynamic created a breeding ground of workplace bullying. Faculty members most targeted, and most likely victimized, have been those most respected and trusted by students, and those who are viewed by students (and others) as capable, hard-working, and respected. Aggressive tactics I have witnessed first-hand include verbal and nonverbal aggression in public settings (e.g., at all types of meetings), and regular occurrences of manipulative and underhanded tactics of psychological abuse and humiliation. Faculty members who do well at the University of Oklahoma are those who pursue their own best interests, those who use difficult situations to leverage more resources for themselves, and those continually-honed impression management abilities far exceed their ability to actually engage in effective teaching and meaningful research with students.

pros: I would say that working for the state government is a lot easier than working for a private company, in that you earn more PTO than you would have gotten from working for another employer, you get the benefit of a due process (if you ever get disciplined for anything), and management for the most part has bigger fish to fry than devoting their time micromanaging you. You can be as independent as you want. Well, at least as far as academics is concerned. I have never worked with people in finance, accounting, or research. Therefore, I can only relay my own personal experience in academics.
cons: When I say that the work environment here is flexible, I meant it in a good way AND a bad way. How is it bad? Well, with the generous PTO that all full-time employees get per pay period, some people (including those in management) will take full advantage of it and disappear for days or weeks at a time. Sometimes, they would disappear during busy periods, leaving their department short-staffed and resulting in heavy workloads, no lunch breaks, oh and missed deadlines because some of these people are the key decision makers whose signatures are needed. I felt that the training for my role was sub-par, and ambiguous, and everything is a guessing game until you eventually learn from your mistakes. One circumstances at a time.

review_title: Resident Adviser is a difficult position for a student
pros: There is a strong and positive community among Resident Advisers. Students will find that it is possible to work on homework during work hours occasionally. One can gain a lot of interpersonal experience from this job: interacting with supervisors, coworkers, and students.
cons: Supervisors are hit-or-miss. While the job is touted as "part-time" and supervisors emphasize that every employee is "a student first," work interferes with school quite regularly. Posted hours, staff meetings, and scheduled work time doesn't do this so much; it's the irregular work (Tour days, following up with a student, hosting events, mandatory staff events) that come in conflict with academics. This would have been mitigated with some good communication, but unfortunately, communication was frequently lacking. Because of the nature of the job, you are "on call" 24-7 unless you are on a pre-approved work leave for the day.

review_title: My experience at OU was really good compared to other jobs.
pros: Reasonable bosses and work load, they'll work with you and with your schedule, and they are willing to help you out. Most job locations are in walking distance from anywhere on campus, and there are plenty of housing opportunities near by so the commute is easy.
cons: Very strict on NCAA policies if you're working with the athletic department, some departments require you to dress up, so if you work right after/before class you'll have to dress up for class too. Had a difficult time initially getting my paycheck due to some flaws in the system, but we eventually got it all worked out, I just got my first paycheck a little late.

pros: The hours are flexible, especially around finals.  Pay is excellent if you can handle calling people for four hours per night.  In addition there is something really cool about speaking with alumni who attended the same university as you 20, 30, 40, 50 years ago.  Fairly high turnover (typical for this type of work) so you get the chance to meet lots of people.  It's easy to leave this job feeling more connected to the University of Oklahoma.
cons: Supervisors come and go, sometimes bringing drastically different managerial styles.  Management sometimes has a difficult time firing people who should be fired for acting inappropriately at work.  Can be either really fun or quite vexing, but as stated managers come and go.  Just hope the fun/qualified ones stay.

pros: Work study job, very flexible, you literally tell them what hours you are typically available and they open up an account where all the departments of OU have acess to pick you up each week when they need you. You have to be notified of a job 24+ hours in advanced, and can only be picked up two weeks in advanced maximum. They also give you the chance to schedule yourself during your available hours if you will be busy with school, etc. (obviously this time is unpaid).
cons: Minimum Wage makes it hard to put yourself through school on this job alone. The experience is not always relevant to your major, and some departments never pick up SWAT workers. Thus, for some, SWAT does not provide any relevant experience to their degree.

pros: Benefits are really good. Leave time is awesome too.
cons: Employees aren't being treated equally. Pay is horrible. When you apply for other jobs on campus it's a waste of time. The only way to get out of the bad departments is to quit and start all over again.

review_title: It is what you make of it!
pros: OU has good benefits and is mostly quite family friendly. How comfortable the work environment is certainly varies by office and the personalities within ... but there is no doubt the university is a true bureaucracy at its core. I have worked in offices in Outreach and later on main campus in Norman. OU is so broad in its scope there is a lot of opportunity if you are motivated to pursue it. Quite decent pay scales, too.
cons: Managers without management skills. I have been lucky to only have had bad experiences with two out of the six managers I have worked for over the past 15 years. But in both instances, HR just said "OU does have a problem with bad managers." Thankfully, there aren't many, but the ones that are there are allowed to continue without training.

pros: Paid for Room and Board. Got to meet many people. Got to meet President Boren. The marching band serenaded us in the morning, which was awesome.
cons: I was left to pay 500 out of pocket, not really a con, but still a minor inconvenience. Maybe it's just me, but serving my fellow peers was not fun, especially when they were rude and they were in the same class as you...just saying. Also, you didn't get to choose which food place that you were to be employed at the beginning.

review_title: No training available at the University.
pros: Stable environment with reasonable expectations for a long-term position. The benefits are better than many other large companies. The retirement package is a lot better than many other companies.
cons: Management isn't able to understand when employees need to take more than a day off for personal reasons. It seems like a foreign concept to many of the managers when an employee has something outside of work that needs attention. Management also seems incapable of telling an employee that they are doing a good job, but they are more than willing to yell at you for the smallest mistake. Training opportunities were pretty pathetic especially considering it is a University - they want you to attend training, but then won't allow you time to go to it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros:
The graduate student education at the University of Oklahoma varies by department. I would say the best thing about being a graduate student has been the opportunity to connect with others in my field. The department has brought it people from all over the United States for the graduate students to interact with. Additionally, many of us have been able to travel all over the world to attend international meetings.
I also appreciate the graduate student life office and staff for all the do.
cons: The student health insurance is probably the worst part about being a graduate student at the University of Oklahoma. They might as well say the graduate student health policy is "don't get sick".

review_title: OU-Tulsa is a great place to work at any stage of your professional life
pros: OU-Tulsa is a great environment to work in.  The benefit package is very generous, campus is very pretty and facilities are   new and up to date, the main campus is in the center of Tulsa so it is an easy drive from anywhere (a large mall is across the street for lunchtime shopping and dining); other clinics are also convenient to everything. Free 24/7 fitness center on site. Lots of career growth opportunities and community spirited, service oriented environment.
cons: This is a state employer so some salaries are not as high as the private sector,  but the benefits and leave package are the best around.

review_title: Not Worth the Stress or Misery
pros: Some strong professional development available.
cons: Highly politicized workplace. Cliquish and unprofessional. Top down micromanagement of teachers in an attempt to keep students happy. Students have too much power over decisions regarding instructors and the run of the school. Teachers are blamed for almost every student problem, thought, or action. Teachers are nit-picked and scrutinized by management. Workload is not justified by the pay. Zero community or support by upper management. Ethos of the schools is corporate, not educational. Work environment is toxic since the changes that have taken place.

job_title: Student Tour Guide in Norman, OK
pros: Very laid back optimistic atmosphere, the work was never strenuous, when you aren't on schedule to give a tour, you organize folders, roll up OU t-shirts, deliver documents to different departments, occasionally watch the receptionist desk. You are trained extensively. Get to make your schedule for the entire semester and if you can not make a shift you simply find someone who can cover for you. You will become very comfortable speaking in front of large groups and this gives you a chance to work on your speaking skills
cons: The pay is great but the job isn't difficult. Tours go through all kinds of weather but more often than not they will make for a great story.

pros: Great community. Everyone tries their best to include you in the OU family and takes time to get to know you. Football school so people bond over that and other sports. Great services and benefits through the HR department and the city of Norman is very diverse and has everything you'd need to live.
cons: The Oklahoma weather and living in a state that doesn't seem to care for education (reduction in funding and opportunities) are by far the biggest negative. As a teaching assistant I'm not making nearly as much as I could be making at another institution.

pros: Loved the work.  Most of the faculty and students were great to work with.  I learned much more than I expected to....
cons: Being bullied by my co-worker (starting week one) who partnered with two faculty who did not want students in their program - enrollment application suppression.  I don't play games with a student's future.  Chaos reigned.  No consequences for their behavior tells you exactly who is in charge.  It took me 5 months and therapy for the drama to figure out what was going on.  Much easier to walk away when you have clarity.

review_title: Good...except for all the required trainings
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: The university is beautiful and staff are friendly. The supervising professors for the assistantship were helpful. The stipend was reasonable given the cost of living in Norman. The position came with some good benefits, like tuition waiver (which could apply to summer classes) and health insurance through the university.
cons: Graduate assistants are forced to do numerous trainings that are not always applicable. For example, the required training on human research was entirely outside my area of responsibility as a GTA, but I still had to do it.

job_title: Student Supervisor in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Access Services specifically had ridiculously free scheduling. While other departments assigned you shifts based on your class schedule, in AS you were allowed to decide your own hours pending approval by the supervisor.
cons: No mobility whatsoever for students. Started as a book shelving slave, and as a student supervisor I only made 50 cents more per hour than when I started. Zero respect from staff or administration, who never seemed to understand what our department actually did.

review_title: No paid leave and overtime work
pros: library is good. Employer pays employer's medicine insurance.
cons: Always be asked work overtime, even on Saturday without compensation. It is not only one lab but popular in several departments. If you don't use your vacation time, you will not get compensation when you leave (It is the university rule for employee who supported by grant). High balance of vacation time is not rare to see (you could figure out why). Getting a retire plan really depend on your direct supervisor for grant support people. In several departments, to my best knowledge, I only know a few people get those benefit.

review_title: University of Oklahoma Health sciences Ceneter -College of Pharmacy, Oklahoma City
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Good stipend--$24,000 USD per annum.
Cheap cost of living.
Course work is relatively less stressful.
cons:
Immense politics--I was a PhD graduate student, department politics forced me to quite with a Master's.
No reputation of the university, at least the college of pharmacy. college of medicine is a reputed program.
Graduate experience lacks scientific thinking- just work to your mentor's wishes.

job_title: IT Support Technician II in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Had a great boss, who was located off site made for a interesting experience and helped me to learn to work unsupervised. Pay was average, but the benefits were good.  Overall my experience here was good.
cons: Lack of willingness to be flexible with hours, OKDHS management at the location I was at was terrible. I worked as a OU employee on a OKDHS contract and dealing with OKDHS was never a good experience. Don't work on OU's OKDHS contracts, stick with the jobs on campus.

pros:
Nice benefits, decent pay.
School Spirit is amazing.
Job security.
Beautiful campus
Co-workers are friendly and nice
Very family oriented
Casual Friday!
cons:
Limited upward mobility within the department. 
Lack of stern leadership and accountability.
Don't expect to get raises.
If you're not an OU alum or from Oklahoma, good luck getting hired.
Lack of diversity and cultural sensitivity.
Few opportunities for professional development and growth.
Privacy is limited to the size of the office space.

pros: I had a really simple job working in OU's office of admissions for the Student Worker Action Team. The pay was minimum wage, but the hours worked well with my schedule. I liked the relaxed atmosphere and how nice everyone was.
cons: As a student who took classes during the day, I wasn't able to work that many hours, so I didn't earn that much money. It would be a great gig for someone who takes mostly evening classes. Also the work was a bit dull sometimes, but I was able to listen to NPR or the radio, so that wasn't even all that bad.

review_title: Great scientific level for graduate school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: I am part of the Chemical Engineering program. There are very good faculty members with topics in the latest advances in technology. All from catalysis, reaction engineering, thermodynamics and simulations, bioengineering and novel materials.
cons: More on the administrative side, some times procedures and rules are not well communicated and misunderstandings are easy to happen. But there is always grace to resolve any issue.

review_title: Meaningful work with great benefits, values, and work/life balance
job_title: Marketing and PR Specialist in Norman, OK
pros: If you want a career in higher education, this is your place. Some of the pros include: commitment to employee development and learning, annual satisfaction/performance reviews, work/life balance, desirable benefits package, employee loyalty, and fair compensation. Access to lectures, arts and sporting events (for a price, of course) was also a plus. Also, Norman is a charming, inexpensive town.
cons: It's what you'd expect working at a public institution. Bureaucracy. Politics. Opportunities for advancement can be limited. Leadership and senior management is a bit of an ol' boys club.

pros: I've worked for multiple departments for the university and the experience really depends on which department you work in. The last department I worked for was lucky enough to have fun and engaging staff and administrators, which made everything I did enjoyable.
cons: Some departments have trouble with administrators being a bit out of touch with staff and faculty, and others have trouble with staff and faculty that don't like to interact with each other. It really is a mixed bag and sometimes you get unlucky.

review_title: Great place to do a postdoc in engineering
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Norman, OK
pros: Friendly people.  Highly knowledgeable in their areas,  Good faculty and infrastructure. Payment if competitive with other universities.  Norman is a quite place and has OKC at just 20min.
cons: Professors are too deeply into business.  Usually I would say this as a pro, but in this case is in detriment of education.  Graduate students do not interact enough with their advisors.  They lack of strong PhD programs, because most of the students just do Masters.

review_title: This position offers a lot of responsibility to a student employee while also ensuring flexibility of schedule.
job_title: OU IT Learning Spaces Technician in Norman, OK
pros: The best part of working as an IT technician is the degree of professionalism cultivated in each employee, combined with the autonomy of the environment and job. Succeeding here is like a benchmark for success in even more professional settings.
cons: Can be physically and mentally challenging, and even frustrating at times. Coworkers who have a weaker background in computers or A/V tech have confided that they feel "stupid" compared to more prepared coworkers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros:
Getting to learn to use various equipment in the lab, may it be for running a reaction or may it be for a characterization technique. 
Having fellow students working with you in the lab helps you become a good team worker. 
Research always teaches you to be knowledge driven and result oriented. It makes you a patient and disciplined engineer.
cons: You keep on working on a pilot scale basis. The inquisitiveness regarding the same process on a large scale is always there. Joining the industry as a production or process engineer would be the correct step towards answering the question.

pros: Lots of paid time off and holidays. Good retirement package. Average health benefits. Overall job satisfaction varies greatly between departments but I'd say the majority is on the good side. Very stable organization so layoffs are a rarity.
cons: Salaries aren't always competitive with surrounding organizations. Low turnover rates sometimes limits upward mobility. Some employee's are self driven but without performance incentives there are others who are ok with being below average.

pros: Laid back environment. Lots of paid vacation days per year. Beautiful surrounding and atmosphere. Financial assistance with education. Decent health benefits.
cons: Poor pay. The staff are seen as dispensable and treated like 'glue on your shoe' by many of the faculty and directors possessing PhD's. Political. Who you know. Disorganized and lacking in communication.

pros: GTA positions in my particular department provided good leadership and teaching experience.  Gives you an opportunity to provide input on laboratory portions of courses. Your interests or experience can be taken into account for what courses you teach. Good rapport with instructor.
cons: If you have no previous teaching experience the orientation only does so much.  Some courses are more supervised than others, so you may have to structure your own lab lectures.  Some courses require way more work outside of class (grading, etc.).

pros: Awesome part-time jobs that get you experience, a paycheck, and tuition waiver with incredibly flexible hours (your boss is usually on your committee and is personally invested in your success as a student first and foremost).
cons: No real cons that could be applied to the assistantships universally, though I am sure everyone's mileage will vary with their unique experience with their particular faculty-employer.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: One of the best facilities I've ever experienced! The faculty present are driven, yet congenial and are constantly seeking the best opportunities for their students. The department uses an experimental education model so it does not always follow the "semester" schedule, meaning there is flexibility and variety in the content and ways you are learning.
cons: The demand on first year students is rather high. I believe there is a lot of "extra" work that will not have to be repeated in future years, but it makes the first two semesters a drag.

pros: The OU Library system is doing some really cool things with technology in their space. They still handle traditional library roles, but branch out into more interesting stuff. I was a student worker in one of their newer spaces. I enjoyed it most of the time. Can be exciting if you jump in and get your hands on things, can be pretty boring if you don't.
cons: As a student worker, the likelihood that you'll be doing something interesting is pretty low.

pros: I enjoyed working with my boss and coworkers. Very little drama and very little expectations. It is a progressive and laid back culture with very little stress.
cons:
The jobs can be monotonous and employees are not encouraged to take on more responsibilities. Administration seems to care very little about their staff and continues to hire from outside with very high salaries, which is seen as an attempt to push out staff. 
Almost no raises or bonuses.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: A seemingly unending supply of resources.  Their research campus is state of the art with brand new buildings and more on the way!  The University of Oklahoma has heavily invested in STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) programs.  David Boren and Lee Williams are the best leaders any college could ask for.
cons: The governor of Oklahoma, Mary Fallin, is no friend of public education leading to increases in tuition costs in recent years due to chipping away at its budget.  She recently cut off budget funding traveling expenses...

review_title: IT: politically charged, no merit or performance raises/promotions, ideological with no execution
job_title: Information Technology Specialist II in Norman, OK
pros: Benefits, location, coworkers, customers, campus experience. Being so close and involved with students, faculty and staff, and an active learning community.
cons: Promotions and raises are few and only for those who have played the political game. No merit or performance raises.

pros: Housing and Food Services is by far one of the most supportive departments on campus. Their commitment to the success of their graduate assistants is apparent, and they consistently make efforts to incorporate the views of their staff.
cons: Despite having multiple expensive projects in the works the department has yet to update the living quarters for it's live-on personnel.

pros: Works great with students for scheduling. Lenient, but effective policy on tardiness due to potential conflicts with class, professor office hours, etc. Great team attitude
cons: There is not much room for raises, but that is to be expected in jobs of this nature. Taking on a lot more responsibilities through promotion results in very minimal raises.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: It's easy for you to find a good balance between work and life coz there isn't much working pressure here.
cons: Most PhD students here perform ordinary research so it's not a so good place for those ambitious guys. There isn't as much cutting-edge research as other top universities in the U.S.

review_title: Consistent, but Management is a mess
pros: Consistent work, will not ask for extra resources in normal times. People are friendly but are very low paid compared to rest of the city.
cons: Management style is often controlled by politics. Low pay for any worker that is not in middle positions, bad for sustaining value for rent around the area.

pros: My mentor is very kind and driven making it easier for me to get publishable data. I feel that the other PI are the same. Some of them of the best in there field.
cons: Very close knit group that is hard to get accepted into. I'm outgoing and feel like an outside after 2 years.

review_title: Easy to work for, but very impersonal.
pros: If you are a student, they work around your school schedule so that you can work up to 30 hours a week without too much stress.
cons: Raises are virtually unheard of. Being able to get any type of promotion passed through the University is very hard.

pros: They are very flexible with your schedule and willing to work around your class schedule to get you the most available hours at the best times for you. The pay is good ($10/hr) and the people in the office are very friendly. Work is easy and not too demanding.
cons: When it gets slow, it is very slow and there is hardly anything to do in the office, however this allows for time to work on class work.

review_title: Great Employment opportunity for student workers
pros: Flexible schedules for full time students and allows for networking to those students interested. Once you are an employee for several years it easier to transition to a full time employee for the students who might want to work for the university after graduating.
cons: Mininium wage, no room for advancement

pros: Flexible work hours , great hourly pay, and good practice in self management. I enjoyed working with my co workers and my mangers.
cons: I have worked there for two months and still haven't gotten paid. It takes a while to get the new employee paperwork through, but this is kind of ridiculous.

review_title: The school does a lot with limited resources but perhaps reaches to far.
pros: School spirit, working towards common goals,  strong reputation in specific areas,  easy to work across intellectual silos, working hard to improve research environment
cons: lack of resources, inability to get rid of dead wood,  poor support from legislature, small size limits access to larger federal resources

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: Most of the faculty and teachers are willing to help each other out. The atmosphere at the University of Oklahoma is strictly positive! They all have a winning attitude!
cons: The pay could have been better. . .  Travel funds for students and teachers are also fairly limited. . . No other cons really to speak of.

pros: Easy to do homework if you are a student. Very accommodating for your school schedule. Scheduling system is excellent and can be synchronized with calendar easily.
cons: Wages are unlivable without having external income. Mobility is not based on success metrics, but on how well of friends you can become with managers. Many employees are not doing any work and are rarely punished for it.

job_title: GRA In Human Relations in Norman, OK
pros: The University of Oklahoma is fully committed to its faculty and staff. It is clear that if it is in your best interests it is in theirs as well.
cons: As you will find in any academic institution. Politics get in the way of progress. Grudges get in the way of collaboration. And laziness gets in the way of healthy confrontation.

review_title: Great employer, a nice sense of community, good work environment
pros:
I love the campus, people, history, and type of work. 
   Good benefits
   Excellent paid time off
   Generally good work life balance
I would suggest employment seekers apply!
cons: Raw pay may not be on par with similar industry jobs. Advanced education is preferred in most scenarios if not needed to move up.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: I really enjoyed my time as a graduate research assistant. Both staff and faculty were accommodating of academic pursuits as well as professional and work experiences.
cons: Stipend for graduate students is a bit low, made it hard to live comfortably. Few opportunities for positions after graduation.

job_title: IT Support Specialist in Norman, OK
pros: Laid back environment, small office with good employees to work with. Generally simple work, most days are fairly slow. Get to wear jeans on Mondays and Fridays
cons: Work is very repetitive, basically doing the same thing over and over everyday. No bonuses and small chance of getting a raise.

pros:
Flexible work schedule
Not very demanding jobs
Nice time off
Nice campus scenery
cons:
Complete morons are in all major positions of authority making way too much money.
No matter how much progress is made in a project some genius will decide to go in another direction and waste time and money.
The university is incredibly behind in technology infrastructure and systems are completely disjointed.

pros: OU offers many benefits to their employees, and allows students to concurrently be employed to assist in paying for their living expenses.
cons: Job requires a lot of time and effort to ensure accurate grading of assignments. Time management and patience are critical skills to have.

review_title: A great place to work and continue your education!
job_title: Payroll and Personnel Specialist in Norman, OK
pros: Lots of opportunities both professionally and personally. Diverse group bringing a mix of cultures to the table. Family-friendly work environment.
cons: It's Oklahoma so the pay is not as high as other places but the cost of living is less so it works out.

pros: Good benefits (though becoming more costly), decent work ethic, overall interest in undergraduate teaching. Campus is lovely and the library has decent resources, depending on your field. Student body is generally hardworking.
cons: It is a R1 university, so the focus on research is heavy. This is problematic when teaching gets emphasized more each year. Funding is stressed, so pay increases are few. Politics always an issue.

pros: It has a good environment to work and study at the same time. My co-workers were very friendly. They offer good opportunities to grow as a professional.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about my time at the University of Oklahoma. I enjoyed my time working there.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: I've worked for the university for 2 and a half years now as a student and the hours are flexible, the staff is polite and welcoming, and the atmosphere can't be beat.
cons: I can't think of any at the moment to be honest! Everything about it is just phenomenal.

review_title: Good research facilities but bad for diversity and pay
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: The research facilities are great and the health care benefits are good
cons: GTAs at OU are overworked in many departments, particularly in the humanities. In some departments they even teach a full time course load while being classified as "part time," and there are a lot of problems at the school with racism and sexism. Also many of the buildings on campus are not ADA accessible

pros: I had a really great boss who allowed me often switch my hours around and take some time off when needed.  I heard the same thing from many of the other employees, as well.  I also liked working with students all of the time, and seeing them; they were always very courteous.
cons: Just hated not having anywhere to park.  Pretty much a pain to always walk so far.

job_title: Full Time Worker in Norman, OK
pros: Good benefits and good opportunities to attend all kinds of events.
cons: No chance of advancement unless you have some sort of degree. Really hard to get a job here. Pay is not great unless you have a degree in something.

review_title: Excellent employer with many opportunities to learn and grow.
pros: Diverse and vibrant community with many opportunities for personal and professional growth. Outstanding benefits.
cons: Salaries are probably not competitive with the private economy. While there are many opportunities for entry- and mid-level careers, there is not much advancement beyond those levels.

review_title: Perfect for a student, not much respect given.
pros:
They work around your schedule.
You can have more than one job/internship.
They are open late providing reasonable amount of hours for employee's.
The job is easy and you can study.
There is usually food provided/good perks.
cons:
Managers/supervisors do not respect you.
A very clique-like environment.
No opportunities for advancement/growth.
No raises.

review_title: I worked at OU for almost 5 years
pros: Flexibility is really the only thing they offer.
cons: Lousy salary, politics are the main-stay.  There are a lot of people who work very hard, but there are also a lot of cronies who do nothing.  The people who do the work get no raises but the Senior VP's always get big raises.

review_title: A work experience to match the education.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Little Rock, AR
pros: Working in an academic environment that provides as much education outside the classroom as inside the classroom; I was allowed to learn from the professors as both teachers in the classroom for schoolwork and as mentors throughout the GA position.
cons: Although the position requires the upkeep of good grades, there are frequent urgent requests from professors for the job which conflicted with school work.

pros: Great place to work, flexible working hours and amazing team of people. For a student job you learn a lot of important skills for your future career. The managers are amazing and they are always there to help you if you need help with something.
cons: I had no problems so far and I  dont think there is any cons for this job

pros: Quiet, less stressful. Very good for family.Very good environment. Nice University town. Good economy. Good sport programs
cons: Isolated, lack of  inspiration. It is not a ideal research University. Good meteorology school and top football program but less impressive academical level. Relative lower salary.

review_title: Great for extra income if you're an independent student
pros: I worked at the Huston Huffman Fitness Center on the Norman Campus as a front desk cashier and as a facility attendant. Coworkers are mostly peer students and supervising staff are friendly, accommodating, and always ready to help.
cons: Pay was hourly minimum wage with little increase in raises.

pros: It was a good, flexible job during the school year. I'd recommend it for a student.
cons: During the summer, it is understaffed and very busy. Breaks become nonexistent. You can't get anyone to cover your shift without paying them extra money from your own pocket to take the shift. There was an instance of somebody who didn't show up for a month - never got taken off the schedule.

job_title: Student Food Service Employee in Norman, OK
pros: You get a pay check if you work there and do your job as you're told, some of the people are nice ish.
cons: Specifically the cafe, If you want to be miserable and leave crying or degraded everyday this is the place for you. I'm sure other places on campus are nice to work at and the management there is fine but the university cafeteria is a terrible that leaves people suffering from depression and want to quit 5 seconds after they set foot in the door.

review_title: GRA at Advanced Radar Research Center
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: World class graduate program in radar and related fields.  Great people, collegial environment.
cons: The radar program has a great national reputation that's getting better all the time, but the reputation of the engineering program here overall is lackluster. You may not get the kind of recognition you would want from people working outside the realm of radar and closely related fields.

review_title: Tutoring, Athletics Dept. University of Oklahoma
job_title: Lead Social Sciences Tutor in Norman, OK
pros: Working in Athletics has its ups and downs. There are a variety of employees here (corporate types, undergraduates, graduate students, retired PhDs). You get to set your own hours and availability, have a lot of flexibility in teaching and tutoring students on an individual or small group basis.
cons: Office environment is stressful due to NCAA compliance tensions, very high turnover rate.

review_title: My experience during my Master studies was in one word: Excellent
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros:
-I loved Norman to be a small-college town.
-Experienced a lot of cultural interaction from everywhere in the world. People are friendly and very open to all international students.
-Professors are very helpful and open to any student.
cons: -Tornadoes is a bit of a problem during spring, intense weather but I don't have any complains about the University.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: Working at the University of Oklahoma had great benefits of working with individuals in my same age range and those with differing ideas. We were able to work together creatively to create content using video cameras, sound recorders, and more in the video production learning and teaching environment.
cons: The parking at the University of Oklahoma is the biggest headache most students and employees will face.

review_title: OU Listed as One of 25 Best Universities to Work For
pros: Overall experience and location in the heart of Norman, OK is a plus with lots of entertainment and opportunities for students.
cons: Dilapidated and dungeony buildings with lack of decent bathrooms like George Lynn Cross Hall, with racist faculty (that often go unnoticed) must be reprimanded  and punished. The basis of their selection to the university is not whether the faculty is from an ivy-league school, but proper knowledge of the subject and the ability of that individual to guide others to similar positions like theirs. Working with a bunch of people with no knowledge of the English language made it very hard for me even to communicate on a daily basis, leave alone their spying endeavors and bigoted attitude. No work ethic in terms of the Supervisor/Faculty being there in time for daily work, honoring appointments for one-on-one meetings, and husband- wife combos that bring family matters during seminars and discussions, and fool around laughing and giggling during serious discussions. Consumption of alcohol during Friday's seminar when school is still in session is an absolute no-no where underage undergrad students are also participating. This eliminates the possibility of a faculty trying to be a role model. Until these faculty are identified by the Chairs and the Dean there is no redemption for the department. In my view point, OU is by no means a great place to work and develop a serious work ethic as given in your recent review!!

review_title: Good Place to be a Teaching/Research Assistant
pros: I was an Research Assistant for one semester. Now I am a Teaching Assistant. I like the working environment. Each GTA has his/her own office desk.
cons: There are too many students in one section and there are a lot of HW to grade.

review_title: Some great people at OU, but overwhelmingly political and clique-ish.
pros: Love college football tradition and passion of alumni and community; some of the strongest academic programs in Oklahoma.
cons: Very political atmosphere with promotions and opportunities based on favors and insider information instead of performance; cronyism rampant.

review_title: A generally good a flexible place to work.
pros: It was a student position and my managers were always flexible and understanding. They really all seemed dedicated to their jobs and invested in the purpose of their projects. David Boren is a awesome guy.
cons: It was just minimum wage. There weren't always a lot of hours to be had. It was not the most interesting work.

review_title: Great, thoroughly enjoyed my time working as a grad student for the School of Meteorology.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: Technology was top notch, professors were very knowledgeable with open office doors, provided plenty of computing power to get the job done.
cons: The overall feeling I had was that of a hands-off growth approach to grad students with little unsolicited advice or guidance given. For some, this may prove challenging.

review_title: Did research with multiple professors on campus, on interesting topics, as part-time work.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Norman, OK
pros: University work: lots of exposure to advanced topics. Fun town, lots of art, etc.
cons: Grad student life is hectic; few protections. They don't really take responsibility for the welfare of grad students in some departments (mine is great though)

review_title: OU a great place to work... just wish to ocean was a little closer
pros: cost of living, housing is very well priced, and as such you can live in a great home within minutes of the university.... good work prospects, football is great and the university is solid.
cons: no where near the ocean...

review_title: university of oklahoma faculty and administration
pros: outstanding administrative leadership, R1 flagship university, elite faculty, excellent research funding, respectful, supportive environment

pros: The benefits for this job are excellent. Also, the people you work with on a daily basis are some of the best and brightest minds you'll find in Oklahoma.
cons: The only down side to this job is that some days can be front loaded with work and others can me very mundane and slow.

pros: My advisor was not only the best mentor but also made my transition - coming from another country -  smooth. Hones, serious organization.

review_title: A fun and eventful job that allows you to get to know regular golfers on a personal level.

Relaxed atmosphere
Great place to work when the weather is perfect
Other employees that are easy to get along with
cons:
Management has a tendency to be overly strict
Days of Tournaments are long and tiring

review_title: A great place to work with.
job_title: IT Analyst II in Norman, OK
pros: Great benefits, many opportunities for you to try many different things.  Provided you have the heart to pursue.
cons: Some departments been tied down by their top level.  It needs to open up.

review_title: Good School to do Research Work At

pros: The University has an inclusive culture and room for professional and personal development. Great team environment, good work/life balance, and awesome benefits.

pros: Excellent workplace with flexible scheduling. Working for the university has quite a lot of benefits apart from job. The people are good to work with and there is room for advancement.

pros: The work give a professional skills in catalysts and in fundamental chemical engineering concepts around of the research in biofuels

review_title: Good place to work for busy college student

pros: OU considers faculty, staff and students part of the OU Family.  The work life balance is amazing here.  The flexibility in schedules promote work-life balance.  Now offering tuition free for dependents if they are on your health insurance.

review_title: Very good benefits and stable job position
pros: Very good benefits and stable job position. Very friendly colleagues and nice environment. You can get at least three weeks of PTO.
cons: Salary promotion is badly affected by the low oil price. Payment is not comparable with industrial level. Another thing is the retirement plan of Oklahoma teachers is in big deficit.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Norman, OK

review_title: For a student it is good. Norman is not an expensive place and you can definitely make it on whit they give you
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Norman, OK

pros: Best job ever! As a student it allows me to have a great work/life balance, as well as allowing me to keep up with my schoolwork.

review_title: An ok experience, not superb, not horrible

pros: Very flexible and very good pay for students on campus. I was also able to complete homework during work hours

pros: Can be a very collegial, pleasant environment with lots of brilliant people and opportunities.

pros: The leadership is flexible, supportive, and all around appreciative of your education/work balance.

pros: Students are able to study while on the clock because you do not work nights or weekends or holidays which is great as a student

review_title: University of Oklahoma Libraries - Great place to work

pros: Friendly working environment, good pay, part-time, student job, easy to learn, opportunity for promotion, great boss, great leads, not too hard.

job_title: Security Officer in Oklahoma City, OK
